solution_line_template: The cheap gym cost {cheap_monthly}*{months_in_year}=$<<{cheap_monthly}*{months_in_year}={cheap_yearly_fees}>>{cheap_yearly_fees} for monthly fees
The more expensive gym cost {expensive_multiplier}*{cheap_monthly}=$<<{expensive_multiplier}*{cheap_monthly}={expensive_monthly}>>{expensive_monthly} per month
That means the sign-up fee was {expensive_monthly}*{expensive_signup_months}=$<<{expensive_monthly}*{expensive_signup_months}={expensive_signup}>>{expensive_signup}
The monthly fees for the expensive gym comes out to {expensive_monthly}*{months_in_year}=$<<{expensive_monthly}*{months_in_year}={expensive_yearly_fees}>>{expensive_yearly_fees} per year
So the total cost for the expensive gym was {expensive_yearly_fees}+{expensive_signup}=$<<{expensive_yearly_fees}+{expensive_signup}={expensive_total}>>{expensive_total}
